docs.snippet: Unam Pumas became the first team to win back-to-back titles in Mexico when they defeated Monterrey on Saturday in the second leg of the title series.
docs.lead_paragraph: F.C. Porto won the final Intercontinental Cup (aka the World Club Cup and the Toyota Cup) on Sunday and unofficial acknowledgment as the top club team in the world -- as long as ''the world'' is limited to Europe and South America. The competition, between the winner of the European Champions League (Porto of Portugal) and the Copa Libertadores (Once Caldas of Colombia), was settled on penalty kicks. The event began more than 40 years ago and evolved through chaos and controversy, intercontinental recriminations and hard fouls -- a lot of hard fouls.
docs.abstract: FC Porto defeats Once Caldas, 8-7, on penalty kic

headline.main: Porto Is on Top of the 'World'

docs.snippet: The Chilean judge also immediately charged the former dictator with nine counts of kidnapping and one of murder.
docs.lead_paragraph: A Chilean judge ruled Monday that Gen. Augusto Pinochet was competent to stand trial for human rights abuses that occurred during his nearly 17 years as Chile's dictator and immediately charged him with nine counts of kidnapping and one of murder. Judge Juan Guzmán Tapia also ordered that General Pinochet, 89, be placed under house arrest and confined to his mansion on the outskirts of Santiago, the Chilean capital. The former dictator's lawyer, Pablo Rodríguez, accused the judge of trampling on the general's human rights and announced that he would appeal the decision. Later Monday, General Pinochet's defense team filed an injunction with the Santiago Court of Appeals, effectively freezing the house arrest until the court rules on it, according to Chilean news accounts..
docs.abstract: Chilean judge rules that Gen Augusto Pinochet is competent to stand trial for human rights abuses that occurred during his 17-year reign as Chile's dictator, and immediately charges him with nine counts of kidnapping and one of murder; orders that Pinochet, 89, be placed under house arrest and confined to his mansion near Santiago; Pinochet's defense team files injunction with Santiago Court of Appeals, effectively freezing house arrest until court rules on his appeal; all 10 charges against him stem from international kidnapping and murder alliance called Operation Condor, one of whose victims was Orlando Letelier, former Chilean foreign minister assassinated in Washington; Pres Ricardo Lagos has no immediate comment on ruling, but State Defense Council president Clara Szczaranski, who oversees conduct of government officials, welcomes judgment; latest decision reverses earlier court rulings that allowed Pinochet to avoid facing any charges stemming from human rights abuses during his rule; estimated 4,000 political opponents were killed by state security, military and police forces; thousands more were jailed, tortured or driven into exile; photos; chronology of major events since Pinochet seized power in 1973 (M)

headline.main: Chilean Judge Says Pinochet Is Fit for Trial

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: WAR CRIMES, GENOCIDE AND CRIMES AGAINST HUMANITY

byline.original: By LARRY ROHTER; Pascale Bonnefoy contributed reporting from Santiago for this article

docs.snippet: A draft report says U.N. investigators looking into charges of sexual misconduct involving peacekeepers in Congo have been threatened with retaliatory attacks.
docs.lead_paragraph: United Nations investigators looking into charges of rape, pedophilia and prostitution involving peacekeepers in Congo have been threatened with retaliatory attacks, and witnesses have been bribed to change incriminating testimony, a draft report says. The confidential 34-page document details 68 allegations of sexual misconduct by peacekeepers from Morocco, Nepal, Pakistan, South Africa, Tunisia, and Uruguay, and lists incidents where soldiers from Morocco, Pakistan and Nepal worked to obstruct investigators.
docs.abstract: Libyan leader Muammar el-Qaddafi, displaying usual theatrical flair, tells Italian television interviewer that his pledge to give up prohibited weapons won re-election for Pres Bush, and he is waiting to be rewarded with nuclear technology for nonmilitary purposes; says Libya is now partner in war against terrorism, warns that allowing Turkey into European Union would be Trojan horse for Islam and proposes resolving Israeli-Palestinian issue with single state called 'Isratine' (M)

headline.main: Congo Peacekeeper Sex Scandal: Investigators Said to Be Threatened

docs.snippet: Local women in Congo have accused U.N. soldiers of sexually assaulting them, using money and treats as lures.
docs.lead_paragraph: In the corner of the tent where she says a soldier forced himself on her, Helen, a frail fifth grader with big eyes and skinny legs, remembers seeing a blue helmet. The United Nations peacekeeper who tore off her clothes had used a cup of milk to lure her close, she said in her high-pitched voice, fidgeting as she spoke. It was her favorite drink, she said, but one her family could rarely afford. ''I was so happy,'' she said.
docs.abstract: UN has uncovered 150 allegations of sexual abuse committed by peacekeepers stationed in Congo, many of them in Bunia where population has suffered horrendous atrocities committed by local fighters; raping of women and girls is common tactic in war raging in Congo's eastern jungles involving numerous militia groups; Unicef program has treated 2,000 victims of sexual violence in Bunia in recent months; Sec Gen Kofi Annan says there is clear evidence that acts of gross misconduct have taken place in UN mission in Congo; map; photos (M)

headline.main: In Congo War, Even Peacekeepers Add to Horror

docs.snippet: Two peacekeepers are being investigated for sexual misconduct in Burundi after an inquiry into sexual abuse in neighboring Congo.
docs.lead_paragraph: Two peacekeepers are being investigated for sexual misconduct in Burundi after an inquiry into sexual abuse in neighboring Congo, the United Nations said Friday. The soldiers, whose nationalities and reported abuses were not disclosed, have been suspended, said a spokesman, Stephane Dujarric.
docs.abstract: UN says two peacekeepers are being investigated for sexual misconduct in Burundi after inquiry into sexual abuse in Congo (S)

docs.snippet: The quality of farm-raised caviar has improved dramatically, and the amount that is available keeps increasing.
docs.lead_paragraph: IT is time to add new players to the usual caviar vocabulary of beluga, osetra and sevruga: transmontanus and baerii. Farm-raised caviar is becoming a better option than the shrinking and restricted wild harvest, and the sturgeons of choice are Acipenser transmontanus and Acipenser baerii. These terms are showing up on caviar tins.

headline.main: And on the Farm He Had Caviar (E-I-E-I-O)

docs.snippet: Brazil's government-run oil company, Petróleo Brasileiro, said it had reached an agreement to buy a controlling stake in Conecta S.A., a Uruguayan natural gas distributor, for $3.2 million from the Spanish group Unión Fenosa. The acquisition is the...
docs.lead_paragraph: Brazil's government-run oil company, Petróleo Brasileiro, said it had reached an agreement to buy a controlling stake in Conecta S.A., a Uruguayan natural gas distributor, for $3.2 million from the Spanish group Unión Fenosa. The acquisition is the first foray into Uruguay for Petrobras, as the Brazilian company is widely known. The acquisition will give Petrobras a 55 percent stake in Conecta, which distributes natural gas to 4,200 clients throughout the country except the capital, Montevideo. Todd Benson (NYT)
docs.abstract: Brazil's government-run oil company, Petroleo Brasileiro, reaches agreement to buy controlling stake in Conecta SA, Uruguayan natural gas distributor, for $3.2 million from Spanish group Union Fenosa (S)

headline.main: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Petrobras Expands In Uruguay
